1.content: Historian Frederick Jackson Turner wrote his Frontier Thesis, arguing the west was “won,” the frontier “closed,” creating a unique American culture.

2.content: US General Custer’s forces lost the Battle of Little Bighorn in Montana to Plains Native Americans. A stunning defeat that was an outlier in the Indian Wars.

3.content: The massacre of Lakota Native Americans at Wounded Knee (in South Dakota) by US soldiers signified the end of “Indian” resistance in the west.

4.content: The Dawes Act is passed by Congress to make Native Americans farmers not hunters, shrinking reservations and opening excess land to whites.

5.content: The Chinese Exclusion Act was passed after years of nativist complaints about economic competition and  cultural/social fears.

6.content: The transcontinental railroad, an engineering feat using largely Chinese labor, is completed in Promontory Point, Utah.

7.content: The Carlisle Indian School opens in Pennsylvania. The founder, General Pratt, wants to “kill the Indian and save the man.” Children were traumatized.

8.content: Henry Ford’s Model T car was first produced. He used assembly line technology (and anti-union tactics) to keep costs down and profits up.

9.content: The Standard Oil Trust is formed by John Rockefeller to control prices. The trust was deemed illegal in a 1911 Supreme Court case.

10.content: Andrew Carnegie's victory at the Homestead Steel Strike signified big businesses’ power over unions and workers rights.

11.content: The nationwide Pullman Strike, led by socialist Eugene Debs, was put down federal troops, signaling the government’s laissez faire attitude.

12.content: Yellowstone in Wyoming becomes the first national park in America (and the world).

13.content: The 19th Amendment passes, protecting women’s right to vote after Alice Paul put pressure on Wilson to support the federal amendment.

14.content: The Progressive Party, a third party, also known as the Bull Moose Party, contends in this presidential election with Teddy Roosevelt. He loses.

15.content: Teddy Roosevelt pushes Congress to  pass the Pure Food and Drug Act after reading Upton Sinclair's socialist expose of the industry, The Jungle.

16.content: President William McKinley is assassinated by an anarchist; Teddy Roosevelt, a progressive Republican becomes President.

17.content: The NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) is formed to provide legal support for African Americans to fight inequality.

18.content: W.E.B. du Bois publishes The Souls of Black Folk, criticizing Booker T. Washington more accommodationist approach to inequality in the Progressive Era.

19.content: National Origins Act passed that establishes quotas that severely limit immigration from south eastern Europe.

20.content: The Triangle Shirtwaist Fire in New York City brings calls for passage and enforcement of workplace safety laws.

21.content: Fresh on the heels of an economic panic, Jacob Coxey led an “army” of unemployed men to Washington demanding federal welfare and jobs. No help given.

22.content: Progressive Democrat Wilson supports Congress passing the Federal Reserve Act that centralized banking in the U.S.

23.content: Congress passes the Clayton Antitrust Act to better regulate trusts after the limited effectiveness of the 1890 Sherman Antitrust Act.

24.content: John Muir founded the Sierra Club to promote preservationist policy after his successful bid to make Yosemite a National Park.

25.content: Jane Addams establishes Hull House, representative of the settlement house reform movement and the larger Social Gospel movement.

26.content: Satirized by cartoonist Thomas Nast, N.Y.’s political machine boss William Tweed is convicted of fraud and extortion and sentenced to jail.

27.content: The progressive 16th Amendment establishes a federal income tax to better fund the government and its services.

28.content: Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) was established to oversee practices of railroads.

29.content: Jacob Riis’s muckraking reform book How the Other Half Lives is published. While exposing the slums, he largely blamed non-WASP immigrants.

30.content: The wildly popular silent film Birth of a Nation is released, depicting the KKK as heros in ending “radical” Reconstruction. Blackface was used.

31.content: Pendleton Civil Service Act set up a commission to establish standards of merit (versus patronage appointments) for federal jobs.

32.content: The Populist Party, made up of disgruntled farmers and early progressives, support William J. Bryan for president. He loses to McKinley

33.content: William J. Bryan’s Cross of Gold speech articulates the free silver policy that would help indebted farmers.

34.content: The progressive 17th Amendment is passed that calls for the direct election of senators. Previously state legislatures voted for them.

35.content: Ida B. Wells publishes an editorial exposing  lynchings as common in the south and the need for a federal anti-lynching law. It was not passed.

36.content: Prohibition of alcohol is passed in this progressive 18th amendment. It will be overturned 13 years later with the 21st amendment.

37.content: After 3 months of cancer, Victor Qiu hits Platinum IV on League of Legends.
